WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Miss M. Curry
Address: Brown, Sask.
Birthplace: Basingstoke, Cambridge, England.

1. HOUSEHOLD QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1887
Where did you set up housekeeping? Brown district east Whitewood
Where had you been living before that? Dan. Lanes, Canada
For how many people did you prepare meals? 8
How far was it to your nearest store? 5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a month or less
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Tea, sugar, dried apples, syrup, legs, soda

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Strong Bakers
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs. at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.98
How much did you use graham flour? Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 5 miles what year? 1887
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 10¢
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, whole wheat, flour
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? Didn't grind it to my knowledge
Name: Anna M. Curry
Address: 123 Main Street, Cambridge, Ohio

1. What year did you start homesteading in Nebraska? 1875
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Nebraska
   How many people did you have before that? 3
   For how many years did you live there? 10
   How far was it to your nearest store? 1 mile
   How often would a visit be made to the store? Once a month
   What provisions did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Coffee, sugar, dried apples, applesauce, eggs, soda

2. Flour and other grain products
   In what quantities did you buy flour? 100 lbs
   How much did you pay per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.25
   How much did you pay per hundred pounds of whole wheat flour? $1.25
   How much did you pay for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.50
   What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, buckwheat flour
   Did you grind your own flour? Yes
   How much did you grind? 100 lbs

3. Livestock
   What animals did you keep? Cows, chickens
   How many cows did you have? 2
   How many chickens did you have? 100
   Did you raise any vegetables? Yes
   What vegetables did you grow? Corn, potatoes, beans

4. Other
   Did you have any pets? Yes
   What pets did you have? Dog, cat
   Did you have any hobbies? Yes
   What hobbies did you have? Reading, gardening
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 pounds on average.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? About $1.50 per lb.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? No particular brand.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? One gallon size.

At what price? Didn't remember.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Everyone had a cow or a number of cows, milked by hand.

Did you make butter? Yes, made butter.

What was the price of butter? 1 cent per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, how? Guarded and stored packed in common salt.

Did you make butter? Yes, cheese? But little more than late.

What kind of cheese? Cheddar.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef and pork, wild ducks, prairie chickens and tame chickens.

How did you get fresh meat? It was always fresh when it was killed. Purchased from local stores.

How often did you get fresh meat? Once or twice a week.

How did you preserve meat? By salt and brine cure.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not till 1915.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes, what kinds? Ducks and prairie chickens mostly.

For how long? When we could get them.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not much.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh and salted.

Kinds? When we could buy cod, catfish, salmon.

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? What brand was it?

6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black tea. At what price? $1.50.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? $3.00 per lb.

What other beverages were used? None.

And water.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $1.00.

Should you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? The early settlers got their supply from Brandon.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? The first year.

Potatoes Cabbage Carrots Onions

Turnips Beets

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? Didn't have them at all.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Both ways.

What weight? 10 lbs.

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...

Replied: Prunes.

What was the price of prunes? $1.50.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

Apples, raisins, and currants.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

Peas corn beans Saskatoons

Other foods? Some perishable dairy products.

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1920.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1920.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1925.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

Mainly preserving by canning, not drying.

To what extent? Not to any great extent.

Did you make your own vinegar? No, but some people did.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ...From well..............................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...Quartermile south...........

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ...Barrel............

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Wells are a mile closer to the house and the water is pumped now instead of being drawn up by cup and pail.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

If on your farm this water from your house? (pail, barrel, tank)

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

Builds are built all around & do have a good supply of living streams & the upland past.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bath.

If you made your own, did you use lye? .......... good ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Brand.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From the church near by.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Now people still use wood, some times pine coal is used. There are also buckets. Some oil lamps, and a number of gas lamps are used now.

These latter two are recent in the past four years. We always had the wood coal.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) 1852.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? A. Borden Co., St. Louis.

What year was it purchased? 1852. Price? Don't know.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

Iron pans and tin utensils. They were not homemade.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? Sometime around 1860.

Aluminum? About 1875. Not sure.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Everything was put in paper bags by the storekeeper. Later on cardboard boxes. A number of things were always in tins when they came, so I don't know what the people who delivered them have packed. Any that are left were just buried in 1857 when this district was first settled.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level? If so, give details.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There are so many differences. I could not go into detail here.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I still depend on home grown foods to a very great extent, as I live on a farm.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

This questionnaire should have been in many years ago.

When people grew potatoes they always made sure to harvest. Newcomers got their seed from the earlier settlers. Many times people were short of things due to starving diet but just short of some things. We could always grow good gardens here and did. Rhubarb was very good, even in the making up as pie and as fruit.

People always made a place called a root house, in the ground for potatoes, turnips, carrots, parsnips and cabbage for winter storage. There was also separate from the cellar under the house.

Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

This questionnaire should have been in many years ago.

When people grew potatoes they always made sure to harvest them. We came up with seed from the earlier settlers. Many times people were short of things due to starving diet but just about every thing we could always grow good gardens here and did. Wheat was very good there in the making. We used to make root beer, in the ground for potato storage, carrots, parsnips, and cabbage for winter storage. There was also applesauce from the cellar under the house.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and preserved foods instead of home grown and home preserved foods? (Give us many details and dates)

22. Please add other details from your life and family memories.

This questionnaire should have been completed in many years ago.

The answers made me realize how much I knew about my grandparents' lives and what they went through during their time.

They always made a place called a garden for their own use and enjoyment.

There was also a great emphasis on family and community.
